en.Alpha_centauri_desc:
Alpha Centauri
Alpha Centauri is the closest star system to the Solar System, located approximately 4.37 light-years away in the constellation of Centaurus. It consists of three stars: Alpha Centauri A, Alpha Centauri B, and Proxima Centauri. Alpha Centauri A and Alpha Centauri B form a binary star system, while Proxima Centauri orbits them at a much greater distance. Alpha Centauri A and B are similar to the Sun in size and composition, making them intriguing targets for the search for exoplanets and potentially habitable worlds.
See more on Wikipedia
Proxima Centauri
Proxima Centauri is a red dwarf star and the closest known star to the Sun. It is located about 4.24 light-years away from the Solar System, slightly closer to us than the Alpha Centauri binary system. Proxima Centauri is known to have at least one confirmed exoplanet, Proxima b, which orbits within its habitable zone. This has sparked interest in the possibility of finding life beyond the Solar System.
See more on Wikipedia
en.Earth_moon_desc:
Earth
Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known celestial body to harbor life. It is composed of a variety of ecosystems and presents a unique diversity of life forms, including plants, animals, and microorganisms. Earth is home to millions of species, including humans, and its natural environment provides the resources necessary to sustain life.
See more on Wikipedia
Moon
The Moon is Earth's natural satellite. It is the closest celestial body to our planet and has been the subject of study and exploration throughout history. Its surface is covered with craters, seas, and mountains, and its influence on Earth is reflected in tides and other astronomical phenomena.
See more on Wikipedia
ISS
The International Space Station (ISS) is a habitable space laboratory that orbits Earth. It is a collaborative project among several international space agencies and serves as a platform for scientific research in space. The ISS has been continuously occupied since the year 2000 and has hosted astronauts from different countries conducting experiments in microgravity and studies on the effects of space on the human body.
See more on Wikipedia
en.Enhanced_solar_desc:
Solar System
The Solar System consists of the Sun and everything that orbits around it, including planets, moons, asteroids, comets, and other objects. It is located in the Milky Way and is approximately 4.6 billion years old. The Solar System is divided into two main regions: the Inner Solar System, which contains the rocky planets, and the Outer Solar System, which contains the gas giants and icy bodies.
See more on Wikipedia
Sun
The Sun is the star at the center of the Solar System, around which all other objects orbit. It is an almost perfect sphere of hot plasma, primarily composed of hydrogen and helium. The Sun's energy is the primary source of light and heat for the planets, and its gravitational attraction keeps everything in the Solar System bound to it.
See more on Wikipedia
Inner Solar System
The Inner Solar System is composed of the planets closest to the Sun: Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars. These planets are rocky and relatively small compared to the gas giants of the Outer Solar System. Each one has unique features and has been the subject of exploration and study by space missions.
See more on Wikipedia
Mercury
Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun and the smallest in the Solar System. Its surface is marked by craters, cliffs, and plains, and its orbit is the most eccentric of all the planets. Mercury is also known for its extreme temperature contrast, with extremely hot days and cold nights.
See more on Wikipedia
Venus
Venus is the second planet from the Sun and is known for its dense, toxic atmosphere primarily composed of carbon dioxide. Its surface is covered with volcanoes and plains, and its extremely high surface temperature makes it the hottest planet in the Solar System.
See more on Wikipedia
Earth
Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known celestial body to harbor life. Its surface is covered by oceans and continents, and it is home to an astonishing diversity of life forms, including plants, animals, and microorganisms. Earth is the most densely populated planet in the Solar System and is the site where human civilizations have developed.
See more on Wikipedia
Mars
Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and is known as the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish surface caused by iron oxide. It has fascinating geological features, including volcanoes, canyons, and polar ice caps. Mars has been of intense interest for its potential to harbor life and for future human colonization.
See more on Wikipedia
Outer Solar System
The Outer Solar System is composed of the gas giant planets: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, along with their moons and other icy bodies. These planets are much larger than the terrestrial planets of the Inner Solar System and are primarily composed of hydrogen and helium. They are also surrounded by rings and have numerous moons, some of which are quite large and geologically active.
See more on Wikipedia
Jupiter
Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System and is known for its vastness and strong magnetic field. It is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium and has a distinctive banded appearance caused by its turbulent atmosphere. Jupiter has a large number of moons, including the four Galilean moons: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.
See more on Wikipedia
Saturn
Saturn is the second largest planet in the Solar System and is known for its spectacular ring system. Like Jupiter, it is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium, with a rocky core. Saturn's rings are made up of ice particles and rocky debris, and extend thousands of kilometers from the planet's surface. Saturn also has numerous moons, with Titan being the largest and most well-known.
See more on Wikipedia
Uranus
Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and is unique among the planets of the Solar System because it rotates on its side. It is primarily composed of ice and rock, with a relatively small rocky core. Uranus has a faint ring system and a diverse collection of moons, the most notable of which are Miranda, Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, and Oberon.
See more on Wikipedia
Neptune
Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun in the Solar System. It is similar in composition to Uranus and is primarily composed of ice and rock. Neptune's atmosphere is known for its dynamic weather patterns, including the Great Dark Spot and high-speed winds. Neptune has a faint ring system and a collection of moons, the largest of which is Triton.
See more on Wikipedia
Dwarf Planets and Other Bodies
In addition to the planets, the Solar System contains dwarf planets such as Pluto, Haumea, Makemake, and Eris, as well as numerous asteroids, comets, and other small bodies. These objects are found throughout the Solar System and provide valuable information about its formation and evolution.
See more on Wikipedia
Voyager and Pioneer
The Voyager and Pioneer probes are historic space missions launched by NASA to explore the outer planets and beyond. Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 have provided invaluable information about Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, as well as the interstellar space. Pioneer 10 and 11 were the first missions to cross the asteroid belt and study Jupiter and Saturn up close. These missions have greatly expanded our knowledge of the Solar System and beyond.
Voyager 1 on Wikipedia
Voyager 2 on Wikipedia
Pioneer 10 on Wikipedia
Pioneer 11 on Wikipedia

The Solar System is divided into two main regions: the inner Solar System, which contains the rocky terrestrial planets, and the outer Solar System, which contains the gas giants and icy bodies.

Uranus has a faint ring system and a diverse collection of moons, the most notable of which are Miranda, Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, and Oberon.

Neptune

Neptune's atmosphere is known for its dynamic weather patterns, including the Great Dark Spot and high-speed winds. Neptune has a faint ring system and a collection of moons, the largest of which is Triton.

Dwarf Planets and Other Bodies
In addition to the planets, the Solar System contains dwarf planets such as Pluto, Haumea, Makemake, and Eris, as well as numerous asteroids, comets, and other small bodies. These objects are found throughout the Solar System and provide valuable insights into its formation and evolution.

en.Inner_solar_desc:
Inner Solar System
The Inner Solar System is composed of the planets closest to the Sun: Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars, along with their moons and other celestial bodies. These planets are primarily rocky and have smaller, shorter orbits compared to the outer planets of the solar system.,
See more on Wikipedia
Mercury
Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun and the smallest in the solar system. It has a rocky surface covered by a thin layer of regolith, with marked craters due to its lack of a significant atmosphere to protect it from impacts. Mercury is also known for its large variation in temperature between day and night due to its lack of atmosphere to retain heat.,
See more on Wikipedia
Venus
Venus is the second planet of the solar system and is known for its dense, toxic atmosphere composed mainly of carbon dioxide and sulfuric acid clouds. It is the hottest planet in the solar system, with surface temperatures that can reach up to 450 degrees Celsius. Venus is also known as the 'morning star' or the 'evening star' due to its bright appearance in the sky.,
See more on Wikipedia
Earth
Earth is the third planet of the Solar System and the only celestial body known to harbor life. It is composed of a variety of ecosystems and exhibits a unique diversity of life forms, including plants, animals, and microorganisms. Earth is home to millions of species, including humans, and its natural environment provides the necessary resources to sustain life.,
See more on Wikipedia
Moon
The Moon is Earth's natural satellite. It is the celestial body closest to our planet and has been the subject of study and exploration throughout history. Its surface is covered with craters, seas, and mountains, and its influence on Earth is reflected in tides and other astronomical phenomena.,
See more on Wikipedia
Mars
Mars is the fourth planet of the Solar System and is known as the 'Red Planet' due to its distinctive color. It is a rocky world with a thin atmosphere composed mainly of carbon dioxide. Mars has been the subject of numerous space missions, both robotic and human, with the aim of studying its geology, climate, and potential for hosting life in the past or present.,
See more on Wikipedia
Mars Moons
Mars has two small moons: Phobos and Deimos. Both moons are irregular in shape and are composed mainly of rocks. They are believed to be asteroids captured by Mars' gravity and have been the subject of study by space missions. Phobos, the larger of the two, orbits Mars at a very close distance, while Deimos is farther away and smaller in size.,
See more about Phobos on Wikipedia
See more about Deimos on Wikipedia
en.Mars_moons_desc:
Mars
Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun in the Solar System. It is often referred to as the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish appearance caused by iron oxide prevalent on its surface. Mars has fascinated astronomers for centuries and has been a prime candidate for exploration due to its potential to harbor life and similarities to Earth in terms of geological features.
See more on Wikipedia
Phobos
Phobos is the larger and innermost moon of Mars. It is irregularly shaped and heavily cratered, with a mysterious origin that has led to various theories about its formation. Phobos orbits Mars at a very close distance and is gradually spiraling inward due to tidal forces, which may eventually result in its disintegration or collision with Mars.
See more on Wikipedia
Deimos
Deimos is the smaller and outermost moon of Mars. It is also irregularly shaped and heavily cratered, with a surface marked by grooves and ridges. Like Phobos, Deimos has a mysterious origin, and its small size and distant orbit make it a challenging object to study. Despite its diminutive size, Deimos plays a significant role in understanding the Martian system and its evolution.
See more on Wikipedia
en.Jupiter_moons_desc:
Jupiter
Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, known for its Great Red Spot and strong magnetic field. This gas giant is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium. Its vast system of moons includes over 70 known moons, many of which are included in the simulation.
See more on Wikipedia
Io
Io is the most volcanically active body in the Solar System, with hundreds of volcanoes, some of which are constantly erupting. The intense geological activity is driven by tidal heating from Jupiter's strong gravitational pull.
See more on Wikipedia
Europa
Europa is a moon with a smooth, icy surface and a subsurface ocean that may harbor conditions suitable for life. Its ice crust is believed to cover a global ocean of liquid water kept warm by tidal heating.
See more on Wikipedia
Ganymede
Ganymede is the largest moon in the Solar System and the only moon known to have its own magnetic field. Its surface is a mix of two types of terrain – highly cratered dark regions and lighter regions marked with grooves and ridges, indicating geological activity.
See more on Wikipedia
Callisto
Callisto, the second-largest moon of Jupiter, has an ancient, heavily cratered surface indicating that it has been geologically inactive for billions of years. Its low level of activity makes it a valuable record of events from the early Solar System.
See more on Wikipedia
en.Saturn_moons_desc:
Saturn
Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest in the Solar System, renowned for its extensive ring system. Composed mostly of hydrogen and helium, Saturn is a gas giant with an average density lower than water. Its rings are made up of ice and rock particles that vary in size from micrometers to meters. In addition to the major moons, many smaller moons of Saturn are also included in the simulation.
See more on Wikipedia
Titan
Titan, Saturn's largest moon, is notable for its dense atmosphere and surface lakes of liquid methane and ethane. It is the only moon in the Solar System with a thick atmosphere and the only celestial body besides Earth where stable bodies of surface liquid have been found. Titan's atmosphere is mostly nitrogen with traces of methane and other hydrocarbons.
See more on Wikipedia
Enceladus
Enceladus is one of the most geologically active moons in the Solar System, with geysers that eject water ice and organic molecules from its subsurface ocean into space. These plumes are evidence of hydrothermal activity on the ocean floor, making Enceladus a prime candidate for the search for extraterrestrial life.
See more on Wikipedia
Mimas
Mimas is a moon of Saturn famous for its enormous crater, Herschel, which gives it a resemblance to the Death Star from Star Wars. Mimas has a surface covered with craters and is one of the smallest bodies to be spherical due to its own gravity.
See more on Wikipedia
Rhea
Rhea is the second-largest moon of Saturn, composed mostly of water ice with a small rocky core. Its surface is heavily cratered and shows evidence of tectonic activity. Although less geologically active than Enceladus, Rhea's features provide insights into the history and evolution of Saturn's moons.
See more on Wikipedia
Dione
Dione, another of Saturn's mid-sized moons, has a surface marked by craters and ice cliffs. Evidence suggests a past of geological activity, and like Enceladus, it may have a subsurface ocean. Its interaction with Saturn's magnetosphere also makes it an interesting object of study.
See more on Wikipedia
Iapetus
Iapetus is known for its striking two-tone coloration; one hemisphere is much darker than the other. This moon's unique appearance and equatorial ridge, which gives it a walnut-like shape, are subjects of ongoing research. The dark material on its surface may be debris from other moons or from Saturn's rings.
See more on Wikipedia
en.Uranus_moons_desc:
Uranus
Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and the third-largest in diameter in the Solar System. It is unique for its tilted axis, which causes it to rotate on its side. Uranus is composed mainly of hydrogen and helium, with a substantial amount of water, ammonia, and methane. Its blue-green color is due to methane in the atmosphere. In addition to the major moons, many smaller moons of Uranus are also included in the simulation.
See more on Wikipedia
Titania
Titania is the largest moon of Uranus, with a surface that displays a mixture of cratered terrain and fault valleys. This suggests a history of geological activity. It is primarily composed of water ice with a significant fraction of rocky material.
See more on Wikipedia
Oberon
Oberon is the second-largest moon of Uranus and has an old, heavily cratered surface. It is believed to be composed of roughly equal parts ice and rock. The presence of dark material on its surface suggests it might have experienced cryovolcanism in the past.
See more on Wikipedia
Umbriel
Umbriel is a dark moon with an ancient, heavily cratered surface. It is one of the least reflective moons in the Solar System, suggesting it is covered with carbon-rich material. Umbriel's lack of geological activity indicates it has been inactive for billions of years.
See more on Wikipedia
Ariel
Ariel is one of the brightest and most geologically active moons of Uranus. Its surface features large canyons, ridges, and plains, indicating tectonic activity. Ariel has fewer craters compared to other Uranian moons, suggesting a relatively young surface.
See more on Wikipedia
Miranda
Miranda is the smallest of Uranus's five major moons but has one of the most varied landscapes. Its surface is a patchwork of different types of terrain, including ridges, valleys, and cliffs. This suggests a history of intense geological activity, possibly due to tidal heating.
See more on Wikipedia
en.Neptune_moons_desc:
Neptune
Neptune is the eighth planet from the Sun and is known for its deep blue color, caused by methane in the atmosphere. It is the fourth-largest planet by diameter and the third-largest by mass. Neptune has a dynamic atmosphere with the strongest winds in the Solar System. In addition to the major moons, many smaller moons of Neptune are also included in the simulation.
See more on Wikipedia
Triton
Triton is the largest moon of Neptune and is unique due to its retrograde orbit, indicating it was likely captured by Neptune's gravity. Triton has geysers that erupt nitrogen gas and a surface covered in a thin layer of frozen nitrogen. Its geologically active surface includes ridges, plains, and ice volcanoes.
See more on Wikipedia
Proteus
Proteus is the second-largest moon of Neptune, characterized by its irregular shape and heavily cratered surface. It is one of the darkest objects in the Solar System, reflecting very little sunlight. Despite its size, Proteus has not achieved a spherical shape, indicating it has not undergone significant geological processes.
See more on Wikipedia
Nereid
Nereid is the third-largest moon of Neptune and has one of the most eccentric orbits of any moon in the Solar System. Its distant and elliptical orbit suggests it may be a captured object. Nereid's surface is thought to be composed of ice and rock, similar to other Neptunian moons.
See more on Wikipedia
Larissa
Larissa is one of Neptune's inner moons and is irregularly shaped with a heavily cratered surface. It was discovered during a stellar occultation, which is when a star's light is blocked by an object passing in front of it. Larissa's surface features suggest it has not been geologically active for a long time.
See more on Wikipedia
Galatea
Galatea is another of Neptune's inner moons and is associated with the planet's ring system, acting as a shepherd moon for the Adams ring. Its gravitational influence helps maintain the ring's structure. Galatea is irregularly shaped and has a surface covered with large craters.
See more on Wikipedia
en.Pluto_moons_desc:
Pluto
Pluto, once considered the ninth planet, is now classified as a dwarf planet in the Kuiper Belt. It is known for its complex and varied surface, which includes mountains, plains, and ice volcanoes. Pluto's thin atmosphere consists mostly of nitrogen with traces of methane and carbon monoxide. In addition to the major moons, several smaller moons of Pluto are also included in the simulation.
See more on Wikipedia
Charon
Charon is the largest moon of Pluto and is nearly half the size of Pluto itself. The two bodies are tidally locked, meaning they always show the same face to each other. Charon's surface features canyons, mountains, and a possible cryovolcano. The discovery of Charon led to the reclassification of Pluto and its moon as a binary system.
See more on Wikipedia
Styx
Styx is the smallest of Pluto's known moons. It has an irregular shape and is thought to be composed primarily of water ice. Its discovery, along with other small moons, provides insight into the formation and evolution of the Pluto-Charon system.
See more on Wikipedia
Nix
Nix is a small moon of Pluto with a highly reflective surface, indicating it is covered in water ice. Its elongated shape and tumbling rotation suggest it has experienced significant past collisions or gravitational interactions. Nix, along with the other small moons, may have formed from debris created by a collision between Pluto and another Kuiper Belt object.
See more on Wikipedia
Kerberos
Kerberos is one of Pluto's smaller moons and has a double-lobed shape, which suggests it may be a contact binary formed from the collision and merger of two smaller bodies. Its dark surface contrasts with the brighter surfaces of Nix and Hydra, indicating it has a different composition or has been less affected by space weathering.
See more on Wikipedia
Hydra
Hydra is another of Pluto's small moons, characterized by its irregular shape and rapid rotation. Its highly reflective surface suggests it is covered in water ice. Hydra's orbit, along with those of Pluto's other moons, is influenced by the gravitational pull of Pluto and Charon, leading to complex orbital dynamics.
See more on Wikipedia
